tool.name: RXLR Motifs (Win et al. 2007)
tool.description: Find RXLR Effectors of Plant Pathogenic Oomycetes
tool.command: rxlr_win_et_al_2007.py $fasta_file 8 $tabular_file ##I want the number of threads to be a Galaxy config option...
tool.help:
**What it does**
Looks for the protein motif RXLR using the methodolgy described in Win et al. (2007).
The tool requires a protein sequence FASTA file as input, and produces a simple tabular file as output with one line per protein.
Note that Win et al. (2007) used SignalP v2.0, which is no longer available. The current release is SignalP v3.0 (Mar 5, 2007), so this is used instead (with the Eukaryote model).
Declaring a protein to have an RXLR motif requires a SignalP Hidden Markov Model (HMM) score of at least 0.9, with the Neural Network predicted cleavage site between amino acids 10 and 30, with an RXLR pattern after this and starting between amino acids 30 and 60. Additionally the position of any EER pattern after the RXLR is also reported.
**References**
Joe Win, William Morgan, Jorunn Bos, Ksenia V. Krasileva, Liliana M. Cano, Angela Chaparro-Garcia, Randa Ammar, Brian J. Staskawicz and Sophien Kamoun. Adaptive Evolution Has Targeted the C-Terminal Domain of the RXLR Effectors of Plant Pathogenic Oomycetes The Plant Cell 19:2349-2369, 2007.
Nielsen, Engelbrecht, Brunak and von Heijne. Identification of prokaryotic and eukaryotic signal peptides and prediction of their cleavage sites. Protein Engineering, 10:1-6, 1997.
